content:
The "Identity Theft Enforcement and Restitution Act of 2007" amends criminal restitution laws to include payment for time spent by victims to remediate harm from identity theft offenses. It also establishes predicate offenses for aggravated identity theft and misuse of identifying information of organizations. The "Identity Theft Enforcement and Restitution Act of 2007" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, to include organizations as victims of identity theft. It also amends Section 1028A to include organizations in aggravated identity theft offenses. The "Identity Theft Enforcement and Restitution Act of 2007" amends various paragraphs in Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, to include organizations as victims of identity theft and in aggravated identity theft offenses. This includes renumbering paragraphs and inserting new sections related to counterfeited securities and mail theft. The "Identity Theft Enforcement and Restitution Act of 2007" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include organizations as victims of identity theft and in aggravated identity theft offenses, by redesignating certain sections related to tax fraud. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to remove subparagraph (B) in subsection (a)(5) and make various changes to subparagraph (A). Subsection (c) is also amended by removing "(a)(5)(A)(iii)" in paragraph (2)(A). The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code removes subparagraph (B) in subsection (a)(5) and makes changes to subparagraph (A), including the removal of "(a)(5)(A)(iii)" in paragraph (2)(A) and adjustments to paragraph (4) regarding fines and imprisonment for offenses under subsection (a)(5)(B). Amends Section 1030(a)(7) of title 18, United States Code to include threats to cause damage to a protected computer, obtain information without authorization, or demand money in relation to damage caused for extortion purposes. SEC. 7. CONSPIRACY TO COMMIT CYBER-CRIMES. Amends Section 1030(b) of title 18, United States Code to include conspiring to commit cyber-crimes.

SEC. 8. USE OF FULL INTERSTATE AND FOREIGN COMMERCE POWER FOR CRIMINAL PENALTIES. Amends Section 1030(e)(2)(B) of title 18, United States Code to include using interstate and foreign commerce power for criminal penalties.

SEC. 9. FORFEITURE FOR SECTION 1030 VIOLATIONS. Introduces forfeiture for violations of Section 1030. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include criminal forfeiture of property for individuals convicted of cyber-crimes. This includes forfeiting any personal property used in the commission of the crime and any proceeds obtained as a result of the violation. The forfeiture process will be governed by the provisions of section 413. The criminal forfeiture of property for individuals convicted of cyber-crimes is governed by section 413 of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. This includes forfeiting any personal property used to commit the crime or derived from proceeds traceable to the violation. Directive to United States Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and increase penalties for offenses related to computer crime and misuse of personally identifiable data. Factors to be considered include creating an effective deterrent to such crimes. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and increase penalties for computer crimes involving theft or misuse of personally identifiable data. Factors considered include the level of sophistication, financial motivation, loss incurred, and intent to cause harm. The United States Sentencing Commission reviews penalties for computer crimes involving theft or misuse of data. Factors considered include harm caused, privacy violations, impact on government operations, interference with critical infrastructure, threats to public health or safety, and involvement of juveniles. The United States Sentencing Commission reviews penalties for computer crimes involving theft or misuse of data, considering factors such as involvement of juveniles, intent to cause damage or obtain personal information, disclosure of personal information, and defining the term "victim" to include privacy violations. The Commission must ensure consistency with other directives and sentencing guidelines. The United States Sentencing Commission reviews penalties for computer crimes, considering factors like involvement of juveniles, intent to cause damage, disclosure of personal information, and defining "victim" to include privacy violations. The Commission must ensure consistency with directives and sentencing guidelines, account for aggravating or mitigating circumstances, make conforming changes, and meet the purposes of sentencing as set forth in the law. The Senate passed the legislation on November 15, 2007, as attested by Nancy Erickson, Secretary.
